rows.name: help_text
rows.value: This collection of talks gives students practice observing and discussing properties of general objects, especially 2D and 3D shapes.

rows.name: topics_text
rows.value:
**Observing and Discussing** These tasks introduce young students to voicing their mathematical ideas collaboratively. Students observe a situation, and then voice and compare their ideas. Students learn that images and visualization are important parts of mathematics, along with the more numerical aspects of the discipline.

**Standard Shapes** Introduce your students to the basic 2D and 3D shapes â€“ circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon, octagon, ball, box, and cylinder. You may add other shapes to this list, such as oval, semi-circle, right triangle, kite, parallelogram, trapezoid (trapezium), and pyramid.

**Games** Some of these tasks overlap with some of the Short Math Games - e.g. Same and Different, Which One Doesn't Belong.

rows.name: advice_text
rows.value:
**Learning Sequence**
* Lead the students in the new routine. Set the expectations for what they are likely to observe and how they should discuss these ideas.
* At first, you will need to help them with definitions of shapes and with words for describing objects and spatial relationships.
* As your students get comfortable with this routine, gradually step back and let them run more and more of the task.

rows.name: example__intro
rows.value:
These tasks progress as follows:
* Start with simple descriptions, relationships, and definitions
* Then comparisons and identifications
* Then construct and deconstruct scenes and groups of shapes.
